ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Very low workload, but not the most interesting material. Take it as an easy 6th course perhaps. You will learn some useful material, but it will sometimes be a struggle to overcome boredom. Also, don't expect transparent grading (though I've heard it's very lenient).

Honestly, I have no idea what my grade is for the class. It's the last week and we've only gotten back half the work we turned in, so it's a little scary. Otherwise the professors are interesting, the material is very useful I think for any future endeavors in science, and overall the course isn't very work-heavy. I would recommend it to MB&B majors in search of a relatively chill elective.

The material in this class is fascinating, and I feel that I learned a lot. It's different from a lot of other science classes at Yale in the sense that there are no midterms and no final -- you are assessed based on take-home questions and one-page summaries of scientific papers. All of the lecturers are great, but it's taught at the med school and it can be a bit difficult to get to class on time if you have another class immediately before it. Grading is very opaque... there were six take-home questions total, and by the end of the semester we had only gotten three back. I found that the grading was relatively picky, and they did not tell us anything about what the overall distribution of grades would be like. So that was a bit frustrating, but overall I thought this was a wonderful class. Definitely take it if you have any interest in genetics!
